title: Diploma in Ergonomics Workplace Analysis
headline: Free online course on ergonomics methods, task analysis, neuroergonomics in workplace evaluation, and the environment.
description: This free online diploma course on Ergonomics Workplace Analysis introduces you to human factor/ergonomics. You will learn about task analysis and its purpose. You will learn about the psychological fundamentals of workplace evaluation and the types of assessments for mental workload. You will also learn about the effects of the environment on performance. Get started today and improve your understanding of Ergonomics Workplace Analysis.

courseDescription:
This free online diploma course on Ergonomics Workplace Analysis begins by introducing you to ergonomics. Ergonomics is the scientific discipline concerned with the understanding of interactions among humans and other elements. You will learn about the six classifications of Human Factor/Ergonomics Methods as well as ergonomics awareness checklist. You will also learn about task analysis, Miller's Task Description and Cognitive Task Analysis as well as Hierarchical Task Analysis.

This course will then introduce you to biomechanics in workplace evaluation. You will learn about work place biomechanics and human variability, principles of biomechanics calculations as well as global models for safety and hazards. You will learn about the different instruments used for ergonomics analysis; Electroencephalography (EEG), Electrocardiogram (ECG), and Eye tracking. You will also learn the basics of Electromyography (EMG) and how it is being interpreted.

Lastly, this course will introduce you to assessment of mental workload. You will learn about the three types of assessments of mental workload: primary and secondary task performance measure, physiological measures, and subjective rating techniques. You will be able to explain the purpose of neuroergonomics in work evaluation. You will also learn about the effects of thermal, visual and auditory environments on an individual's performance and well-being. Start this course today and improve your knowledge on Ergonomics Workplace Analysis.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this diploma course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this diploma course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison diploma is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital diploma: a downloadable diploma in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked diploma, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked diploma in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All diploma are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison diploma, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison diploma, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our diploma pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to ergonomics workplace analysis. You will learn the definition and purpose of human factor/ergonomics. You will learn about different varieties of domains available in ergonomics as well as the context of application of human factors/ergonomics methods.
topics: Introduction to Ergonomics Workplace Analysis - Learning Outcomes
Introduction to Ergonomics Workplace Analysis - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to task analysis. You will learn about the purpose and the different approaches to task analysis. You will also learn about the psychological fundamentals of workplace evaluation, biomechanics in workplace evaluation as well as the assessment of the physical demands of a workplace.

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Diploma in Ergonomics Workplace Analysis - First Assessment
modules.description: You need to score 80% or more to pass.

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Assessment of Physical and Cognitive Work
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to physical and cognitive work with psychophysiological methods. You will learn about Electromyography, Electroencephalography, Electrocardiogram and Eye tracking. You will also learn about the three types of assessments for mental workload, neuroergonomics in work evaluation and psychosocial aspect of workplace analysis.
topics: Assessment of Physical and Cognitive Work - Learning Outcomes
Assessment of Physical and Cognitive Work with Psychophysiological Methods
Assessment of Physical and Cognitive Work - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to Thermal, Visual and Auditory Environment. You will learn about how the thermal environment has a major influence on peopleâ€™s performance and health. You will learn about how the elements of the visual environment as well as how the auditory environment and noise pollution can have an impact on hearing.

Analysis of Auditory Environment and Noise Pollution

• Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain what is meant by Ergonomics.
    • List the different classifications of human factors/ergonomics.
    • List examples of physical ergonomics.
    • Define cognitive ergonomics.
    • List examples of cognitive ergonomics.
    • Explain the targets of ergonomics for people and organizations.
    • List the different context of application of human factor/ergonomics methods.
    • Outline the challenges for implementing ergonomic methods.

  • Ergonomics Methods

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary 
    • Ergonomics is the scientific discipline concerned with the understanding of interactions among humans and other elements.
    • Physical ergonomics is concerned with human anatomical, anthropometric, physiological and biochemical characteristics as they relate to physical activity.
    • Cognitive ergonomics is concerned with metal processes, such as perception, memory, reasoning, and motor responses, as they affect interactions among human and other elements of a system.
    •  Organizational ergonomics is concerned with the optimization of sociotechnical systems, including their organizational structures, policies, and processes.
    • Attitude, motivation, satisfaction, job design  are studied in organizational ergonomics.
    • Ergonomics aims to improve the whole system performance and reduce/minimize human risk.
    • The different contexts in which we can apply human factor/ergonomics are: a system focus, context of human and performance, interacting parts of a system, and holistic system, emergent properties after implementation and embedded ergonomic practice.
    • The different classifications of human factor/ergonomics are: general methods, collection of information about people, equipment, and environment, analysis and design, evaluation of user and system performance, evaluation of demands on and effects experienced by people, as well as management and implementation of ergonomics.
  • Lesson Summary 
    • Ergonomics is the scientific discipline concerned with the understanding of interactions among humans and other elements.
    • Physical ergonomics is concerned with human anatomical, anthropometric, physiological and biochemical characteristics as they relate to physical activity.
    • Cognitive ergonomics is concerned with metal processes, such as perception, memory, reasoning, and motor responses, as they affect interactions among human and other elements of a system.
    •  Organizational ergonomics is concerned with the optimization of sociotechnical systems, including their organizational structures, policies, and processes.
    • Attitude, motivation, satisfaction, job design  are studied in organizational ergonomics.
    • Ergonomics aims to improve the whole system performance and reduce/minimize human risk.
    • The different contexts in which we can apply human factor/ergonomics are: a system focus, context of human and performance, interacting parts of a system, and holistic system, emergent properties after implementation and embedded ergonomic practice.
    • The different classifications of human factor/ergonomics are: general methods, collection of information about people, equipment, and environment, analysis and design, evaluation of user and system performance, evaluation of demands on and effects experienced by people, as well as management and implementation of ergonomics.
  • Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you should be able to:
    • Explain what is meant by task analysis.
    • Describe the methods of analyzing people's jobs.
    • Describe the reasons for carrying out a task analysis.
    • List the different ways of approaching task analysis.
    • Describe what is meant by cognitive task analysis.
    • Identify the three types of muscles.
    • Describe the structure of skeletal muscles.
    • Describe the purpose of biomechanics in ergonomics.
    • Explain how the physical demands of the workplace can have a negative impact on the human body.
  • Introduction to Task Analysis

  • Assessing the Physical Demands of a Workplace

  • Lesson Summary 
    • Task analysis can be defined as the study of what a user is required to do, in terms of actions and/or cognitive process to achieve a task objective.
    • When designing workplace equipment or product, it is important to understand how these elements of designs are interacting with the people using them.
    • Methods of analyzing peopleâ€™s jobs include: knowing what they do, the things they work with and what they must know.
    • Task analysis is carried out to minimize work activity, design an interface, and structure a work team.
    • The different approaches to task analysis include: task decomposition, knowledge based techniques, entity-relation based analysis, and general method.
    • Cognitive task analysis is a family of psychological research methods for uncovering and representing what people know and how they think.
    • Every movement of the human body both voluntary and involuntary is controlled by varieties of muscles.
    • The three types of muscles are: skeletal muscles, smooth muscles, and cardiac muscles.
    • Skeletal muscles are composed of different fibers ranging from 10 to 80 micrometres in diameter.
    • The membrane covering the muscle is called sarcolemma, it consists of an inner true plasma membrane and a thin outer layer of polysaccharide with numerous collagen fibrils.
